awd_titl_txt: Asset Allocation: A Statistical Learning Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will contribute to the advancement of national prosperity and economic welfare by developing new and improved methods to solve optimal asset allocation problems. Portfolio optimization problems involving allocation of resources across multiple assets are of fundamental importance in financial management and are faced daily by financial institutions, asset managers, pension plans, university endowments, insurance companies, and individual investors. Beyond finance, portfolio optimization problems arise in other industries, such as portfolios of drug development projects in the pharmaceutical industry, portfolios of research and development projects in the technology industry, portfolios of energy generating assets in the energy industry. This award aims to improve out-of-sample performance of asset allocation methods by building on recent advances in machine learning. The award contributes to the education and development of human resources by providing research opportunities to students and enriching student experience at undergraduate and graduate levels by bringing challenging applied problems in asset allocation to the classroom.

The pioneering work of Markowitz on mean-variance portfolio optimization laid the theoretical foundations of applying optimization to the asset allocation problem.  Notwithstanding the enormous importance and influence of these classical contributions, the fact remains that, from an empirical point of view, Markowitz-style portfolio policies are often outperformed by the naive 1/N equal weights portfolio policy out of sample due because of limitations associated with estimating statistical parameters from historical data.  This project modifies the classical Markowitz portfolio optimization by introducing a new portfolio optimization framework inspired by recent advances in machine learning and econometrics.  A partially egalitarian least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (PELASSO) building on the celebrated LASSO regression was recently introduced in the econometrics literature in the context of solving the problem of optimally combining different forecasts.  Inspired by these recent developments, this project employs the PELASSO portfolio optimization approach by regularizing the portfolio optimization problem to assign portfolio weights of some of the assets to zero and to select and shrink weights of the surviving assets in the portfolio towards equal weights to hedge against parameter estimation risk. The PELASSO portfolio optimization aims to achieve improved out-of-sample performance and is evaluated empirically using rich data from high frequency econometric sources.  The project utilizes methods at the intersection of optimization, statistics, machine learning and economics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project developed, computationally implemented and empirically tested a new portfolio optimization method, Partially Egalitarian Portfolio Selection (PEPS), for allocating available funds among risky assets in an investment portfolio. The new method generalizes the classical Markowitz mean-variance portfolio optimization method with a formulation that penalizes the mean-variance optimization with Partially Egalitarian LASSO (PELASSO) penalty terms inspired by the celebrated LASSO regression in statistical learning and its recent novel variant in econometrics known as PELASSO regression.

The key empirical observation in the asset allocation investment practice underpinning the motivation for the new method is that the naive equal weighted 1/N asset allocation rule that includes each asset with equal weight (N assets included in the portfolio with the 1/N weight for each asset) typically outperforms Markowitz's mean-variance optimization and its many descendants out of sample due to difficulties with statistical estimation of means and covariances from empirical data. The PELASSO penalty term selects the weights of some of the assets to zero, while selecting and shrinking weights of the assets surviving the selection process in the direction of equal weights. Thus, the new PELASSO portfolio optimization formulation includes the classical Markowitz mean-variance optimization as one limiting case where both penalty parameters tend to zero, as well as the equal weights 1/N portfolio rule as the opposite limiting case where the selection parameter tends to zero and the shrinkage parameter tends to infinity. As such, the PELASSO aims to outperform both the Markowitz optimization and the naive 1/N rule, as those are its opposite limiting cases.

The difficulty of the problem is that the resulting model formulation is non-convex. The project developed a computational algorithm that solves the PELASSO portfolio optimization formulation at scale for large portfolios and empirically tested and validated it on multiple datasets with up to a thousand assets. The computational implementation developed in the course of the project solves the non-convex optimization problem by converting it to a mixed integer optimization (MIO) formulation. Empirically testing on seven different data sets validated favorable performance of the PEPS method relative to an array of classical portfolio optimization methods. The PEPS method outperformed the classical methods in virtually all cases tested. In particular, it has done at least as well as the equal weights 1/N rule even in those cases where other classical portfolio optimization methods significantly underperformed the equal weights portfolio strategy.

The intellectual merit of the project is in the development, computational implementation and empirical validation of the novel portfolio optimization method. The broader impact of the project is on the asset allocation practice, as the new method potentially remedies the out of sample shortfalls of the classical portfolio optimization methods in the investment practice, as well as in the development of human resources for the US financial services industry by educating PhD students in advanced mathematical, statistical and computational methods.
